Nov 23 2009 	Pleasant central HI Express Times Square South	We stayed at this hotel for 2 nites this past weekend. The hotel is squeezed in between 2 other affialiated hotels, a candlewood suites and a hampton inn. Location is on 39th street,about 150 feet from the corner of 9th ave-- 4 block walk to times square. 9th is better to walk at night to TS as 39th street is mostly businesses closed by 6pm and deserted. Rooms are compact on the order of a Eureopean hotel room, with about two feet of space on the side of the K bed near the window. Breakfeast and free internet are available, making for a nice savings on the rate. Rooms are quiet-we were on the 32nd fl and heard no street noise nor from adjacent rooms-4 rooms to a floor, 36 floors. Hotel is less than 1 year old so rooms are fresh and comfortable. One of the elevators seemed to be fast and the other slow. Staff is friendly and hotel concierge is helpful. Nearest subway is 8th/42. Good restaurant choices in Hells Kitchen area/restaurant row-try our favorite, Hell's Kitchen for upscale mexican and Basiliica across the street for the prixe fixe pre-theatre special. For theatre tickets, 50% off tyr the Visitor's Ino Cetner at 7th/53. All other things being equal , because of the location, I would stay at the Marriott Courtyard Times Sq on 40th/7th as that hotel is better situated toTS and more amenities. See prior review.	
Nov 5 2009 	Fantastic experience	We stayed for a week in the Library suite. We have two teenagers so it was ideal, as the full height sliding screen effectively creates a second bedroom. Its really spacious - amazing for Manhattan - with full kitchen and dining facilities. The high ceilings also add to the atmosphere. You wont find anything else like it in New York - the complete opposite to the standardised chain hotel room. Its more like a high quality guest house, with each suite occupying one floor. So dont expect a lift, fitness centre, restaurant or swimming pool. But do expect to feel you're someone's guest. The location is perfect - close enough to shops, attractions, museums etc yet far enough away to be quiet. Also the Metro is close by - we had an unlimited metrocard which worked well. And the Metro station is on an express line as well. The service is spot on - always there, friendly, will respond to all reasonable requests, yet is unobtrusive. The fridge is stocked and restocked with everything for a good breakfast together with homemade cake and nibbles. One morning, as we were about to venture out into the rain Alana offered us umbrellas. We have only a few small gripes, and none of this impacted on our enjoyment. The room was quite dark so we had the lights on all the time. Locking and unlocking the front door is quite an involved exercise.	
Nov 26 2009 	Great location; would definitely return at the right price	I stayed here in November for a quick weekend trip. I wanted to be in Chelsea because I was going to the Joyce Theatre twice during the weekend. The hotel is in a great central location in Chelsea with lots of great restaurants and the Highline a very short walk away. Yes, the rooms are very small. I have only stayed in a smaller room once (at The Paramount in mid-town). It worked for me because I was by myself and had very little luggage since it was only a two night stay. I got a really good rate on the property's own website - $139/night - and I would not hesitate to stay here again at that type of rate. I would probably not stay here at a rate higher than say $210 or so a night. (When I tried to add on the preceding Thursday night to my weekend stay, they wanted $299 for it.)I had a room on the 2nd floor on the west side of the building so I had absolutley no street noise from 8th Ave. I could hear every time someone on my corridor opened and closed their door but fortunately it was not a big problem. The lighting in the room was great. The room did have a moldy smell that I noticed as soon as I walked in - I think the bathroom shower tile was the culprit. The free wireless Internet was great but... it blocks vpn access so I ended up using my Verizon card much of the time.	
Nov 4 2009 	Delightful little hotel nestled in the midst of all the action in Time Square.	My 18 yr old daughter and I stayed at the hotel for 6 days in Oct. This was my second trip to NYC. I had stayed at a larger more pricey hotel on Times Square fall of 2008. I had read the reviews and liked the location so I chose Hotel 41.What a cozy little hotel! The hotel is in a great location to the bus stops, theaters, shopping, eating, and countless other tourist attractions. It was quiet, clean, and the staff was friendly and very helpful with inormation and directions. It is on a block off Times Square, but only a very short walking distance and you are on Times Square. The hotel is one block from the Broadway district, which was ideal. Every a.m. the hotel serves bagels, pastry, juice, coffee etc. The room was quite small, but it is NYC and we did not spend much time in our room. I was looking for a hotel centrally located to everything and reasonably priced and Hotel 41 was a hit! I plan to return to NYC in two yrs. I will not even consider another hotel. I travel often and Hotel 41 was a wonderful experience. As I said, small, quiet and clean!If you are looking for a fancy hotel with large rooms Hotel 41 is not for you. If you want a quiet, clean hotel with easy access to Time Square and Broadway, bus stops, shopping, eating etc then Hotel 41 is for you.Marilyn, Green Bay, Wi.	
	Best location!!!	We stayed from a Monday morning until the Friday evening, and had no complaints.With 5th Avenue a few seconds walk away, the Rockefeller Plaza and Centre just over the road, and Central Park less than ten minutes, we couldn't have chosen a better location. We had already read a review, telling us that the hotel was good for business or just couples (not families) because the rooms are small. Who plans to stay in their room much, when in New York, anyway?! Check-in was quick. The hotel felt new and was really clean. The cleaning service for our room, was exceptional, -even though we would've saved on towels and re-used, there were clean ones daily, along with new bottles of shampoo, body lotion, mouth wash etc etc. We didn't eat in the restaurant, so cannot comment on that, -only because we were always out and about, though, and had other plans....we didn't even ever have breakfast in the hotel. -we were drawn to the Concourse level of the Rockefeller, for breakfast, on several occasions, -as such a good variety, and brilliant places to sit, watching the world go by. We had poured over SO many ideas for a New York hotel, but, in the end, picked one that was ideal.	
Nov 22 2009 	Still working out the kinks	I took advantage of the rough draft special at Ink 48- 48% off normal rates. Note to those reading: the normal rates are incredibly high for a hotel located in a neighborhood of car dealerships (but relatively close to times square).I booked a junior suite and was housed on the 11th floor in an amazing gorgeous room. Note that despite being absolutely huge those rooms have only one moderate size window that looked out on the hudson river. The room had a gigantic soaking tub and an amazing shower. Unfortunately on my first morning in that room I was awoken to a loud jackhammering noise coming from the single window in my gigantic room. It turns out that they are actually still removing bricks (or something like that) from the rear of the building (and they were doing it to the floor below mine. I cannot believe that they would actually house me in a room that would be adjacent to that sort of work on at 8:45 on a Saturday morning. When I called the front desk I could not even hear what they were saying over the noise of the work.As a result of the mishap I was upgraded to a stunning (even more gigantic) full hudson river suite, which had walls and walls of windows. It was an amazing quiet room. If I were to book rooms again I would go with the full hudson river suite over the jr. suite. This hotel has to have some of the largest rooms in all of manhattan.All in all I probably would pick another hotel over Ink 48 because it was too much out of the way. I am still amazed that Kimpton would have jackhammers working outside an 11th floor suite, but the front desk handled the matter very well. I'm certain with time things will fall into place.

Oct 3 2009 	Too far from the heart of New York	The main issue we have with this place is that it's not a motel / hotel set up - it's run by private owners and basically there are only 3 rooms spread throughout the terrace (not the entire terrace like what we thought was the case). Location is too far from heart of new york. It's a 20 min train (at least) to Times Sq as it's on a non-express train. Personally i think it's a waste of time travelling up and down each day esp when you are a tourist. With this in mind the price is rather steep for such a neighbourhood.Rooms and facilities are still ok - but of course sans housekeeping so you will be better off getting a lower class hotel in the city with about the same price. Bear in mind also their cancellation policy.overall i think it's not too bad but just not my cup of tea and definitely not deserving of the reviews/ranking it has so far. i don't mind staying here if i am on a working stint but not as a tourist strap for time and needing the basic internet.

Nov 23 2009 	Great Location -	I just got back from NYC with my husband and six year old daughter. We stayed for three nights at the Night Hotel. We booked through Priceline and we got a good deal. I don't really care about the decor or the fact that it's trying really hard to be this &quot;goth&quot; getaway while the majority of travellers staying at the hotel were anything but goth. What really bothered us was the way we were greeted at the front desk and the lack of pretty basic hotel services. After we booked online with Priceline, my husband called the hotel to request a king bed. He was told that they wouldn't guarantee the request, but they would try. That was fine. When we arrived at the hotel we were greeted at the front desk by a less than pleasant employee who loudly told us (and the rest of the lobby) that because we booked with Priceline we would be getting the cheapest room in the hotel. We could upgrade to a king for an extra $30 a night. We chose to take the &quot;cheapest room&quot; in the hotel. There was nothing wrong with the size of the room (it's NYC - space is at a premium) and a queen size bed was fine.Rather than concentrating on the black and white interiors and the nude photos in the front lobby, or the music pumped into the halls, or the business cards with your name on them and words &quot;in residence&quot; printed for you, they need to concentrate on a few other things. Things like sheets that fit the bed (they use flat sheets that aren't big enough so they pull out from the under the mattress), replacing used or almost gone supplies (we had to ask for toilet paper, shampoo and conditioner), and ensuring that the &quot;queen&quot; sized bed is just that. My husband is 6'2&quot; and I am 5'11' and we both spent the night cracking our ankles on the footboard. There was also absolutely no natural light in the room. We took to calling it the bat cave.We travel a lot. We are accustomed to small boutique hotels and so is our daughter. If the hotel only wants a certain type of travellers then don't advertise on Priceline, especially in the section where you don't know what you are booking until after your bid has been accepted. Needless to say, we won't be back and we wouldn't recommend it either. It is in a great location. We walked everywhere we wanted to go.

	Fancy a Luxury trip to NewYork HILTON GARDEN INN TIMES SQUARE	Spending christmas vacations is always awaited by everybody . But when it comes to making your trip to the destination and then come the major task of selecting which hotels , that will suit your budget and also will be a great leisure time , thus making your trip memorable and worth spending your money .So we decides to make a trip to New York as my wife had always planned to go for . Then game a big job of which hotels , when searching for many sites, we came up with a good portal for making online bookings with . that was Hotels2stay.net . we chose to opt for NewYork HILTON GARDEN INN TIMES SQUARE ,, First of all I would say it was really a remarkable stay at this hotels .The hotels served all the services to its fullest .e Hilton Garden Inn Times Square's seating area includes a fireplace and features red, brown and yellow decor. Black and white portraits of New York City are displayed throughout the hotel. Pigalles restaurant serves French cuisine. Complimentary coffee is served each morning at the restaurant. The hotel's fitness center features cardiovascular equipment and is open 24 hours. The hotel includes two workstations with complimentary wireless Internet access and complimentary printing.Bathrooms include Neutrogena toiletries and curved shower rods. In-room safes are laptop compatible. Complimentary newspapers are delivered to the guestrooms. Accommodations include coffeemakers, and room service is available.The Hilton Garden Inn Times Square is located in New York, N.Y., one block from Broadway. The hotel is in the Theater District in Midtown Manhattan. Blue Line service at the 50th Street subway station is two blocks from the hotel and Times Square is two blocks away in the opposite direction. Radio City Music Hall and shopping on Fifth Avenue are three blocks from the hotel. And with all this and more me and my wife made romantic stay at this Hotels , and definitely to be thankful to the Portal that made our stay wonderful as we made bookings through them at cheap rates as compared to other sites .Good Job Done Hotels2stay.net !!love to make bookings with them again . And thanks to the services put up from Hilton garden .

Nov 8 2009 	Great for the second time!	This was my second time staying here since August 2009 and I was, again, very satisfied. Stayed one night with a friend. Booked room directly through Hilton (I never use sites like Expedia, Hotels, etc.). I booked the room initially at $259 but I checked the rates on the site frequently and the night before saw the rate was now $189. So, I applied for the rate change right on the Hilton site and got the room for $189. I wonder how many people are aware you can do this? It is definitely a money saver!The room was on the 7th floor. Honestly, it was of less quality than last time, still clean and sufficient, don't get me wrong, but it was definitely smaller and the view was of the roof. I think last time we were on a higher floor, maybe 15 (if it goes that high?)But again, there was nothing wrong with the room itself, the staff is so great, friendly and accommodating, I'm sure they would have given us a &quot;better&quot; room if we cared to complain, but it really wasn't a big deal just to sleep. Just want to let people know, the higher rooms seem to have the better views if that's what you're looking for.Free breakfast in the morning, great again, coffee, juice, bagels, muffins, fruit, sausages, yogurt....Easy check-out, free internet in lobby, literally less than 5 minutes from the subway. Can't beat it!	
Aug 28 2008 	PC was a great temporary home	I lived at PC for a few months while my new apartment was renovated. (Note: PC is very popular for this; a high proportion of the guests here seem to be New Yorkers between homes; also a sprinkling of movie and TV stars in town for a gig.) You can rent a studio, one, or two bedroom (all with a kitchen) by the day, week or month. The rooms/suites are stylish, modern and comfortable. Great big flat-screens, Bose sound system, attractive lighting, nice kitchen and bathroom. My one-BR was quiet. PC's lobby is kind of stunning, I always felt special walking through it. PC's location is terrific, not just for Lincoln Center, Columbus Circle, and all the conveniences nearby like Barnes &amp; Noble, the gym, Balducci's, etc. Also it's a block away from the 1 and 9 train and several Broadway bus lines, so you can get around town easily and inexpensively. What I liked the best about this place was the staff. The doormen, desk people, housekeeping and maintenance people, they all give top-notch service. They were unfailingly friendly and helpful. The moment I had a problem, they were on it. They can arrange anything - car service, in-room massage, dry cleaning, messengers, show tickets, you name it. I felt very well taken care of at PC and I recommend it highly. My only caveat is that it's expensive. But you get what you pay for here.

Bathroom: really really small. Bed: really really small and too soft so if there's 2 of you prepare to cudle all night long because you'll sink to the midle. No views.So, try another hotel. With the amount of money Shoreham costs you'll find other hotels, also well located (if not better) where you have a bed where you can actually sleep.It takes more than white walls and funny lamps to be a modern luxury hotel. 	Great location - Bad value	Apart from the amazing location, which this hotel charges a lot for, it is not a great experience. Everything, and I mean everything, costs extra. Checking out is not a peasant experience when you are hit with such a large bill	
	Great location 	This is a great hotel for location and transport links. The rooms are very large for New York, clean, with large clean bathroom. There is use of an ironing board and a free safe in the room - would definitely return here when next in NYC.	
	Great hotel great location!	I stayed here for 5 nights with my dad from November 14th-20th. Check in was quick and easy, we were given a room on the 10th floor with a view of the Empire State Building. The rooms were of good size, we had a twin bedroom and were pleased with the size. There was also an electronic safe in the cupboard that was free to use and the rooms were cleaned everyday. Breakfast was fine - we thought we would probably have to go out and buy breakfast as it was only continental but there was plenty of choice and always enough food to go around. It was a buffet style breakfast with muffins, cereal, toast, youghurt, bagels etc and tea and coffee which you could help yourself to throughtout the day and night. The hotel was great location wise - down the road to macy's and empire state and about a 5-10 minute walk to times square. Beware though it IS the city that never sleeps - I don't think I had a night where I slept straight through without being woken up by a binman at 3am or noisy people coming back to their hotels. Our window was also broken the first night which meant the noise was awful but the staff did fix it straight away the next day so I have no complaints with that.The hotel also sell tickets to most attractions for exactly the same price as the attractions themseleves which is handy and means no queuing!! The staff are friendly and are really helpful, they reccommended a boat trip that we didn't even know about and it was fantastic. We did all of the main attractions and walked to most of them. People are quick to tell you to get in a taxi to get everywhere when you can walk it in 10 minutes!! We walked to central park from the hotel and to John Lennon's old house but people couldn't understand why we walked the 20 minutes to get there... The only place we did get the underground to was to Ground Zero and you can walk from there to the Statue of Liberty dock in around ten minutes if that.When you get given the map everything seems really far away... but it's not. Save yourself some money and walk, it really doesn't take that long and there is so much traffic on the roads it's not worth getting in a taxi.The security over there is immense so be prepared to be prodded and poked! It's good considering everything that has happened and makes you think that Britain should be the same. For Top of the Rock, Empire and Statue of Liberty you get searched and go through metal detectors etc before you can go up, understandable and makes you feel more secure plus it doesn't actually take that long.Coming to and from the airport we booked with Supershuttle.com before we went. Excellent service, you can tip when you book (tipping is a huge thing over there and most places if you go out and eat will actually add their own tip on..then ask if you want to leave anymore!!). We shared the ride with about 4 other couples and it did take about an hour to get to the hotel but it gave us time to take in the sights and sounds so we didn't mind at all. Going home we were the last to get picked up and the ride took about 20 mins! It's cheaper than getting a taxi they have a flat rate of about $43 one way. One final thing... I have to reccommend Keen's steak house. It is literally round the block from the hotel and was the best meal I've had!! It was expensive but well worth it. Don't go around 5/6pm though all the businessmen go there for their dinner and it gets stupidly busy. We went on a Sunday and it was quiet. Lovely place, excellent staff and fab food.	
	Great location combined with a luxury hotel.	I thought the Hotel Gansevoort was an ideal combination of location and hotel. As a first time visitor to NYC, I really enjoyed the trendy neighborhood (ie., great restaurants, shopping, and clubs). The Chelsea food market, Magnolia's bakery, STK - to name a few. It makes me salivate just thinking of these culinary delights! The hotel is modern and tastefully appointed. The room was very comfortable and offered a spacious bathroom. I certainly appreciated many of the little details that had been included in the room. Some hotels promise - Hotel Gansevoort delivers. The staff were extremely helpful in assisting us with our local destinations - suggesting great night spots, transportation routes, and other miscellaneous details. It made our vacation the best trip of our lives!

	Suite did not match description -- not 5 star service -- got food poisoning	After a long conversation on the phone with a reservations assistant, and after carefully reviewing the descriptions on the internet, I selected an Edwardian Suite with 1000 square feet, a living room with a sofa, and pocket doors between the living area and the bedroom. Well, they put us in a room that they insisted was in fact an Edwardian Suite, but it matched identically the description of the next lower tier suite that was several hundred dollars less--no pocket doors, about 700 sq feet, no room for a sofa. They moved us after one night (were sold out the first night), but did not refund the difference in price. The first night was uncomfortable as we had no privacy from the children and the rollaway beds barely fit in the room, and they were saggy. The next night, the REAL Edwardian suite was lovely. But we had to go to the trouble of moving and really didn't get to enjoy it. There were some other problems: no chicken fingers for the kids (ran out for two days!) though eventually they cooked some from scratch for us (shouldn't have been that hard!) And, after eating ONLY hotel food the whole day, I got a mild case of food poisoning in the middle of the second night, which kept me up for several hours. Luckily I was ok again the next day. I think it must have been the salad I ordered.	
	Customer service par excellence!	Located just two blocks from Times Sq this small but perfectly formed hotel come restaurant/bar made a great base to explore Manhattan the week before Thanksgiving. We arrived on a Saturday, and this is the one flaw with the place, the bar was VERY loud in the evening, and our room on the 1st floor next to the elevator vibrated with the disco that was going on downstairs. However, the staff were quick to relocate us to a top floor suite for the remainder of our stay at no extra charge (in fact they discounted the first night!). The rooms are well appointed and cosy with a New Orleans flavour. The whole place has a warm, welcoming feel to it, much more friendly than your typical large hotel. Thank you to Tori and her colleagues for making our once in a lifetime visit to NYC a memorable one!

	Nice food but would never go there again.	Okay, so I'll start of my saying that I am a teenager who travels often, so I know my fair share of hotels. I went to New York with my mom and great aunt to visit family and see the city. We chose Novotel because of the pictures that were on the website; they're modern, clean, white with a few colours. When we got there, the lobby was very nice, just like the website had shown, white with accent colours and granet counters. The service was good, pretty average. As soon as we got onto our floor (12th), it was a drastic change. The walls were orange with blue accents and were marked all over. When we got to our room, and turned on the light I almost cried. I was expecting a nice white room, but it felt as if we just stepped into a dingy motel in Arizona or Mexico. The drapes and bedspread were the same generic hotel print, the walls were an odd splotchy orange, with green metal windowframes. I almost expected cockroaches and spiders to come out of the walls. To add to this, the bed was uncomfortable and had lipstick smears all over the pillow. By this time I was upset, because it was a special trip for my birthday, and from the beginning it wasn't what I expected. To make things worse, I had to buy wireless internet that didn't work.The bathroom, however was nice. It was the only part of the room that was modern with very nice lighting for makeup, but the shower wasn't very nice. The shower floor was bumpy, and coming away from the floor. The veiw was also nice, but not the best; we overlooked the top of a dirty building, but in a crowded city it wasn't shocking. The food service was very good! It was one of the best in-room meals I've had.I'm not meaning to turn this hotel off for people, it just is not up to my comfort level. Many people say that they came to the city to see the city, and only have the hotel to sleep. But for me the hote is one of the most important things; it's the place I have to feel safe to get a good sleep in after a long day. I did not feel safe in this hotel. We only stayed for 2 nights, and switched hotels.

Oct 18 2009 	Fabulous stay at The Mark	We stayed at The Mark for 1 night over Labor day weekend. The hotel had just reopened recently. During the time of our stay, it was their &quot;soft opening&quot; phase, where the hotel was not fully completed (restaurant, gym, bar, and hair salon were still under construction). We were a little skeptical because the hotel was very expensive, even at a discounted price, however, we were blown away with the design and comfort of the hotel and room. We were particularly pleased with the service that Andrea, the reception manager, showed to us. He showed us to our room and explained how everything worked.Our room was immaculate and quite honestly the best we've ever stayed in (including Vegas). I'm not sure how the hotel looked before they closed for 2 years, but whatever happened, it was given a complete makeover.The rooms were enormous and very modern in design. The closet space could accommodate anyone staying for about a month. The bathroom was all marble; the tub was long and deep enough for 2 people (I think), and separate shower big enough to fit a party of 5. There was a TV in the mirror of the bathroom vanity, which was very cool. There was a telephone, scale, towel warmer, and professional hairdryer all just in the bathroom.The room itself could be controlled by a universal remote control. The remote controlled the electric shades over the windows, the large LCD TV, Blu Ray DVD player, lights, and air conditioning. Along with complimentary snacks (like pretzels, candy, soda, and water) we were also given a box of cookies that came from a restaurant down the street. Included in the price of the hotel was also a complimentary breakfast, which was great.Overall we couldn't have been happier with our stay at The Mark. And if possible, it's going to be even more amazing once it's fully completed!	
Oct 18 2009 	The Best Hotel in New York City!	Ive been traveling to Manhattan for business for about 5-10 hotel nights/year for 25 years and over the years have stayed at many of the big hotelsGrand Hyatt on 42nd St, Marriott at Times Square, The Plaza, The Waldorf Astoria, The Essex House and many others. I discovered the Lombardy 15 hears ago and have stayed there exclusively since then. It is a small boutique hotel on 56th St between Park and Lex. The rooms are enormous by any standard but especially for NYC. Since the building is a co-op, every room is either a studio or one bedroom apt with a kitchen. Since each room is individually owned they are all decorated differently but the dcor is controlled centrally by the hotel management. An earlier post complained of the dcor looking dated. I disagreeIve stayed in probably 15 different rooms and every one of them is professionally decorated, each with different themes. They are all updated on a regular basis. All of the decorating is high-end, custom or semi-custom design and freshly done. In fact, its always fun to see what theme you are going to get in any given room. It is absolutely the quietest hotel that I have ever visited. The staff are true professionals and the service level is high. Everything you need to live is within a city blockrestaurants, diners, delis, bars, drug store, etc. The subway is 2 blocks away at 54th and Lex. Staying at the Lombardy is like having your own high-end apartment in Manhattan.	
	Very good value hotel with modern style	The hotel is very well located in the midtown area of Manhattan. Within walking distance to two subway stops. Madison park and Union square are also within a few blocks distance. The rooms are not huge but have more than enough space. The decor is modern and the staff is extremely diligent in helping with any request. I would definitely recommend this hotel for any type of travel.

	Outstanding hotel with wonderful staff	I and my girlfriend spent the last week of Nov in New York to celebrate her 30th birthday. We spend the first four nights at the Carlton (see separate review) and the remaining three at The Surrey which was a much better choice in every way. To start off, the location is great, just a few minutes walk to central park and the subway. The inside of the hotel is very elegantly furnished and decorated, including the rooms and truly earns the privilege of being called luxurious!As for the staff, from the doorman to the massage therapist, I'm simply short of words. From start they charmed us and attended to our every need.At check-in we immediately received a complimentary room upgrade due to my girlfriend turning 30 during our stay. After inspecting our wonderful room (with the most comfortable Dux bed and lovely details such as the content of the minibar and the lightning system) and unpacking we decided to skip going out for dinner since we were a bit worn out after hours of shopping and just try the in-house restaurant Cafe Boulud (http://www.cafeboulud.com). Even though we had no reservations and the place was packed, our concierge Michael succeeded to arrange a table for two after just a few minutes. After tasting the first bite of the food we realized that it has to be one of the better restaurants in New York (I almost cried out of happiness after tasting their wild mushroom ravioli - A MUST if you visit the restaurant). When I later googled the place I found out that they had a well deserved star in guide michelin and that the chef has another restaurant in NY with three stars so they definitely know what they are doing in the kitchen.As for the spa, we both had a 50 minute massage which was really good and I used the gym once which had what you need for a few days stay. The ONLY negative thing I can point out about the hotel was that they charged $15 for 24hr wireless Internet which I think should be complimentary at a hotel of this standard.In conclusion, I want to send a special thank to Guy who worked at the front desk and the other concierge we had contact with apart from Michael, Abraham, who really made us feel like home with their exquisite service (we actually miss them). The service was truly more than your average five-star standard and I would go as far as claiming that it could be compared with high end hotels such as the Four Seasons or Shangri-La. I only hope that the staff get the credit they deserve from the management.All in all, our stay at The Surrey was amazing! The hotel is very elegant, classy, and modern hip. It feels like everything you would expect from a five star New York City hotel and I would definitely recommend it to anyone who can afford it. I will for sure stay at the Surrey again when visiting New York in the future.	
	Skyline adds Sparkle to Manhattan...Fabulous Stay!	You know that feeling when you are about to leave home to go somewhere exciting and you're hoping that the hotel you have booked turns out to be amazing? My wish came true. Skyline is more like a 4 1/2 to 5 star hotel. The suites are divine...&quot; a home away from home&quot;. There is soooo much space in the rooms, and they are super clean. The bed is very comfy. Our suite was very impressive and the view was breathtaking... especially in the evening with the manhattan skyline. Location is central. You can walk to the theater district, times square and cabs/subway are very accesible. There is a choice or restaurants or delis nearby. Overall...I had an amazing stay in Manhattan thanks to Skyline Hotel. &quot;It's a home away from home and truelly a hidden Gem&quot;. I would stay here again in a heartbeat!	
	Trendy hotel with well-designed small rooms in a great Columbus Circle location	Like most travelers, I scour the web and the guidebooks for great advice when it comes to my hotel stay. This is expecially crucial if I have booked a room on Priceline (as in this case). I want to correctly set my expectations prior to arrival. For instance, I really had to get myself in the SMALL ROOM mindset before checking in at The Hudson. Arrival: The hotel doesn't have a sign. Be sure to look at the pics on the website so you know where you're going if you are coming in via subway train. There was a small line at check-in but the front desk staff did a great job keeping everyone moving. There was one very important woman (a trendy I-think-I'm-20-but-I-am-really-45) who felt compelled to jump to the front &quot;Just to ask a question&quot; which of course was her attempt to jump the line. No go! Yay front desk. I made a joke and they took pity on us and got us into a higher level room facing the atrium. :-) Score!The room: Ok. We know. It's small. It's not the end of the world. Unpack your stuff. Be organized and you have plenty of room. Don't throw you stuff all over the room. Now you'll need to sit on the toilet sideways and take turns in the bathroom but....the good parts? Incredible water pressure and a roomy shower plus a VERY comfortable bed. You didn't come to New York to hang out in your hotel room did you? Well then, the shower and the bed are top notch. Done. My husband and I slept like logs in a Queen size which is usually a challenge. I think its really all about the pillows. Noise: Try to get a room above the 6th floor. There will be street noise. It's NY. Buy some freaking Tylenol PM if it's that big of deal. The bigger issue is the nightclub. It's loud. Very loud and very popular. Therefore if you are below Floor 6, you will probably hear it. Join the fun or get something to knock yourself out. Location: As they say in real estate....This is a superb location. The subway is very close and can get you where you need to go quickly. We walked down Columbus Ave after visiting the Natural History Museum and really enjoyed it. Great shops, bars and restaurants al the way down. Lots of dogs and locals give it a nice neighborhood feel. There's a great 24 hour diner and pizza place right on the corner of 58th and 9th. Both are open late. We enjoyed our stay very much. Appreciated the thought and design work that went into the place. Staff was very friendly except for one woman carrying a clipboard in the AM who looked at me like a deer in the headlights when I asked her a question about check out.. Overall a good bet. An even better one if you can score it on Priceline.

	Good hotel but a bit far out for sightseeing with a toddler	My husband and 2 year old son stayed here for three nights over the Thanksgiving weekend. We got an excellent rate through priceline and the front desk staff upgraded us to a superior room on the 33rd floor. We had a big room with fantastic view of the hudson and jersey city. There was a small fridge in the room to put milk and yogurt for my son. The hotel is a standard marriot and the rooms are rather large for a Manhattan hotel.The 85 west restaurant has a decent menu but a bit pricy ($20 for a burger). We had breakfast from starbucks one day and the other mornings went to a diner a block away (Georges) which is excellent. I can't compalin about the hotel except I would not stay downtown again for sightseeing or shopping. Also not that many restaurants around.The hotel is one block from ground zero and in general there is a lot of construction in the area with sidewalks blocked off and traffic diverted. The subway stations are very close for getting into town. It is a 20 minute ride to midtown and 25-30 to uptown/central park. All in all, a great hotel but not the most convenient location for midtown sights, especially with a child and a stroller. We also prefer to come back to the hotel for naps and that was inconvenient from midtown as taxi ride is about $30. On the plus side, the ferry for liberty and ellis islands is 10 minutes walk from the hotel.

	Excellent Midtown Location - Great Value	Neighborhood is nothing much, but it's a great location to get to everything, and near Penn Station and Bolt/Megabus stops. Very new and clean. We were there on a Saturday night so noise wasn't a factor, but based on the printed notices in the room, the &quot;white noise&quot; generator in the room, etc. it could be a problem, especially garbage trucks, on a weekday morning - I'd ask for a high floor if you were staying on any night but Saturday. Staff is extremely pleasant and helpful. Rooms of a very decent size for NYC. Restaurant with bar on the premises (for dinner and possibly lunch - no breakfast). Continental breakfast of average quality included in room rate.

Nov 6 2009 	Great Location Tiny Room Clean Good Value.	What we liked best: Great location for broadway theatres and Times Square. What we liked least: Tiny Room. We arrived about noon, and they allowed us an early check-in without any fuss. The hotel location is great - broadway theatres just a block away - Times Square is just two blocks - subway stations two to five blocks distant. The room was clean, but awfully small (the queen bed was about a foot from two walls). The bed was comfortable. The bath was small but serviceable. everything was clean and in good repair. The continental breakfast was nothing special. The hotel website pictures show fruit on the breakfast bar, but we never saw any fruit. The high speed internet worked fine, except for an outage that lasted a few hours. If you want to use the internet, be sure to ask about it when you check in, since our experience was that they didn't volunteer that information. The staff were all friendly, helpful, and knowledgeable.

Nov 25 2009 	Great location staff; would go back	I was at this Hampton for 3 weekender nights in mid-Nov 09. It is but a block walk from Penn Station, which is nice when one has luggage. Right off the bat, the front desk staff were just delightful. Smiling greetings, super helpful and efficient- can't ask for more than that. The front desk always had a smile and a offer of help. Very nice!!! There is a PC in the lobby, though we did not use it; I did see others. Our room was on 16th floor, corner, double beds. It was a little tight, but good enough. Nice flat screen on the wall, which I'm sure, greatly helped in the configuration of the room. There was a desk in the corner with complimentary chips &amp; water and a standing closet next to the window. Like I said, it was tight, but it wasn't bad. Shower was good, though very high up, but stayed hot. We didn't hear alot of noise in the room from the outside but some. Breakfast was nice, though, again, a bit cozy. Cold &amp; hot items available with coffee and juices. Seemed to be replenished quickly. We went all 3 mornings, even though there is a Dunkin Donuts right next store as well as a cafe. Th eonyl down side, if one even want to call it that, was the elevators can be delayed if housekeeping is doing their run. There is no service elevator for them to use. The whole hotel is very space efficient. So be aware of those at mid-afternoon times. Penn is super close, so you can take a subway anywhere and you know at roads lead back to Penn, so really no worries about missing a train. Comfortable walk to Times Sq (or subway), Macys around the corner. All said and done, I would go back to this Hampton. It was $197/night, which is not too bad for the City, but probably can be better if I booked earlier.	
Nov 22 2009 	Lovely but perhaps too much of a club and not enough of a hotel	The title sums it up.SH is located in a fabulous part of twon, trendy, not too noisy and busy, but easy to get to the main event.The hotel itself is great. 	Location is superb hotel is very good very quiet room	My fianc and I spent a few days in New York during Thanksgiving. We had pre-booked the hotel and profited from their &quot;book early - save money&quot;-program. Our room was in the 4th floor; sadly, staff had forgot about my request to have some sparkling wine in the room, so we didn't have that on arriving; but that wasn't a big problem, as the hotel offers complimentary wine from 5-8 pm every night (even with piano music on fridays). The room itself was good, though the bathroom was a bit small, but very clean and nicely done. We had a bit of a problem with the shower in the sense that the water spilled over the sides, and it was nearly impossible to take a shower without splashing the bathroom floor. That also wasn't a problem, as we only had a shower in the morning and then were walking through NYC all day, so we didn't care too much about the wet floor which was cleaned during the day anyway. The reason we only rate this hotel as &quot;very good&quot; and not as &quot;excellent&quot; is that the heating didn't work. It was already rather cold outside and when we asked at the front desk if they could turn the heating on, their reply was, that the heating would be turned on automatically if temperatures dropped below 55 Fahrenheit. Which it didn't. We did get a little electrical oven, though, so we were warm enough. But we would have expected the heating to work in a rather expensive hotel. Rick's Caf on the second floor really is like an extended living room, with some wonderfully comfortable chairs and sofas. we had our breakfast there and enjoyed a glass of wine every evening. We loved the interior decoration of the hotel - it is also very quiet, despite being right on the edge of Times Sqaure. For the Thanksgiving Parade we could really just walk 20 metres from the hotel and were right in the middle of it all. All in all, I'd recommend the hotel; I'd return again, though I might get a bigger room next time.	
	Feel very deflated with regards to my stay at the Barclay	I am a Platinum Ambassador for this chain and really expected to be taken care of as we gave notice that we were celebrating my wifes' 40th. We did get an upgrade to an executive king room but were not impressed with the room. The bathroom was 5feet by 7feet. There was mould where water had leaked into the wall. the lighting was dull and as there was no dressing table the hair dryer and sockets were situated above the WC and my wife had to stand infron of the toilet to curl her hair in dull light. the toilet seat had numerous chips on it and looked awful. We had a cup of coffe each with the fancy new coffe maker and afterwards discovered that we were allowed one coffee a day, (not each), free and any further coffee would be charged at $3 plus tax. Bring back the kettle and free coffee, tea and hot choc please. On our first night we were so exhausted we went to bed at 1830 and were surprised when the doorbell rang at 2130. The cleaner wanted to check out room. It was 0230 in the morning back home and we were shattered. I have never had a visit that late before and rang to complain. I was told that i was at fault for not putting my don not disturb sign out. The room was on the 8th floor and we could not see any sky. The room was very dark and gloomy. The bed was comfy and had a mtress topper. We asked for a room change to a brighter room which never happened. The drinks are expensive. A vodka and coke and a JD and coke were over $20 and 2 breakfasts were $65. The breakfast buffet was quite extensive as expected, but most things were cold. The best thing to eat were the cold bagels with salmon and cream cheese and the freshly made omlettes. I asked 5 times for juice one morning and in the end went and picked the caraffe up myself. The waiter came over and snatched it out of my hand. The foyer is very impressive and the music played by a guitarist in the evening is quaint. The concierge service were keen to assist in helping with things which may gain them commission but were unhelpful with other issues. The online concierge service did not work on my TV either. The Gym is unsupervised and I went on my first morning to have a steam and sauna and found them to be turned off. I rang down and a maintenance came up and showed me how to turn them on. The emergency stop button and timer activate these services. There is no way you can alert anyone if you are in distress and as these services are in the changing rooms they are remote. The fitter said that the alarm is only sounded if the services get too hot. If you require a sauna you need to turn is on for an hour before you go in. the street noice was loud and the glass and garbage trucks woke us up at around 5-5.30. New York was brilliant and we enjoyed everything we did. I would go to New York again but would not stop at the Barclay.

Nov 26 2009 	Nice place to stay in the city	My daughter treated my wife and I to an overnight stay in New York at the Hampton as well as a dinner cruise on the Hudson and East River. We took the bus up from the Jersey Shore to the Port Authority and walked the ten easy blocks to the Hampton on 51st and 8th. We arrived early on a Monday afternoon. We were able to check right into our room, so we were able to unpack and go exploring. It is always nice to get an early check-in. We had a cheap but filling lunch at the beer bar around the corner on 51st. Good burgers and some good brews on tap. I had the ten dollar beer and burger special. It came with a pickle and an ample supply of fries. The burger was home made (not a patty). Back to the hotel. One of the elevators was out of service for our whole stay. The one elevator that was in use was definitely overworked. When we arrived we were taken to our room by way of the freight elevator. People were using it during our whole stay. From a liability standpoint, I am not too sure on the advisability of this practice. My wife and I preferred to use the stairs to our 6th floor room. It was good exercise. The room was of ample size. It had a nice 32 inch flat screen tv. The king sized bed was very comfortable. Plenty of pillows and sheets with a good thread count. The bathroom was small though. There was really room for only one occupant at a time. The shower was hot with good water pressure. The heat - air worked well. There were no loud noises or wild parties. The morning breakfast was very well attended. There were waffles as well as all the other items that one expects at a Hampton breakfast. I wish there were some eggs and bacon though. Perhaps they rotate the menu from day to day. The workout room was small but well stocked with treadmills and other equipment. All of the workers we came in contact with seemed to do a good job. The desk was quite professional. I think we will make this hotel the base of operations for any future New York overnight stays. It seemed very popular so one may have trouble getting a last minute booking.	
Nov 23 2009 	Oasis away from Times Square	I came in for business in the Theater District but was reluctant to stay near Times Square as the tourist scene there makes me nuts. 	Great place to stay while visiting NYC.	The location of this Hotel is Downtown, not Midtown, so if you want to go &quot;where the action is&quot;, you need to go by subway or taxi if you stay at the Wall Street Inn. That being said, staying here was simply a great experience. There is a so much history you just &quot;bump into&quot; being Downtown. We walked alot and learned the subway system, which for me is the way to go. We went as far up as 72nd street to walk through Central Park and go to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. We had 3 full days in NYC and barely scratched the surface of what this city has to offer. I expected Battery Park, The Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island and the World Trade Center to be close by, but to find St. Elizabeth Seton's shrine and the museum where the Magnicarta is held, to be right around the corner were unexpected treasures. The desk staff is not warm, but the cleaning crew always had a &quot;hello&quot; and smile for you. You really can't take it personally. However, it is amazing how many New Yorkers do NOT know where a good restaurant is. So, use your guidebook and map and you'll be fine. It is really hard not to have a good meal when in NYC, BTW. I found this hotel to be a great value and safe bet. Have fun!

The friendliest staff there were the maids and porters who would always say greet you in a kind manner and have a little chat with you.

First off, the hotel elevators were constantly breaking down, and an even more ridiculous thing was that the hotel blamed US for stalling the elevator. They didn't even ask if we were okay, instead they were trying to cast the blame on us for breaking the elevator. The even more ridiculous thing was they didn't even shut it down. There were two elevators, so we avoided the broken one, since we had no interest in plummeting to death. Thirdly, the hotel housekeeping was non-responsive to our requests for cleaning the room, and we were not living cheap either. 	A Good Find in the Upper West Side	We enjoyed our stay at the Excelsior, which is undergoing renovations. We were offered an upgrade to a renovated Jr Suite in the back of the hotel instead of my reservation for a regular King room facing the Museum. However, the smell of new furniture and carpet was a problem for my spouse, so we asked to be moved to an older room. Most people would have been happy with the renovated room, the new TV, and the new furniture. The unrenovated room was nevertheless very nice, spacious and very clean. Although I had wanted a view, in the end I'm happy we didn't get it. The rooms at the back are very quiet, hardly any street noise, and we slept well on a comfortable bed.Staff were pleasant, and a very nice breakfast buffet on the 2nd floor was offered at $12 per person, in a beautifully furnished room.The adjoining restaurant (separate ownership) had a very nice bar off the lobby.The location is excellent. Lots of taxis pass by as 81st is the west side of the 79th St roadway across Central Park. Also the subway to downtown is at the corner.A very pleasant walk across the Park to the Met or the Guggenheim, and across the street is the Natural History Museum and Planetarium.Many good neighborhood (non touristy) restaurants nearby. Great shopping just west on Broadway (again, geared for New Yorkers, not tourists, which is a plus).Prices at the Excelsior seemed reasonable by comparison to other hotels closer to midtown.We would certainly go back.

Nov 16 2009 	Arty doesn't have to equal grimy	We booked the Carlton Arms after reading the website and online reviews. Some things are true - it is one of the cheapest places you'll find, has a good location and no bed bugs or anything bad like that. However, it's quite dirty, dark, and the friendly staff which I've read about didn't seem to be on duty during our stay! The hotel is a few minutes' walk from a subway and from Park Ave, and there are loads of restaurants and bars very close by. The location feels safe and convenient. When we arrived we weren't given a choice of rooms. The one we got was ok. It was on the first floor so only two flights of steep stairs to manage. However, the room was very dark. The beds are the creakiest I've laid on for a while, the sheets were clean but the sink in the room was really, really dirty (rust and general dirt) and I had to restrain myself from buying some cleaning equipment and doing it myself. Also, the window didn't close properly so there was a constant draft (which wasn't too much of a problem as the heating was usually on and the room was boiling hot) but it wasn't great in terms of security. My main problem with the room was that it clearly hadn't been cleaned to any proper standard for years. Yes it had been hoovered but there was a layer of dust on the table and bedside lamp and a generally grimy, student house feeling. It was really noisy at night (street noise through our open window and the banging heating pipes) but I had earplugs so it was ok. We had a shared bathroom which was quite clean and we hardly ever had to wait for it. There was a room where we could leave our luggage when we checked out, and during our stay, there was one friendly guy on the front desk who ws helpful in answering our questions. The rest of them seemed a bit surly and unfriendly. Overall, I'd say that the wesbite is very good and the art photographs well. However I'd like it if they paid more attention to the more boring parts of running a hotel such as cleaning and maintaining the rooms. It's an old building, true, but I wouldn't have thought that dusting the rooms should be too difficult. It really feels like you're staying in a dirty student boy's house.

Nov 25 2009 	Great location but disappointing rooms and AWFUL heating system!	OK so the location was amazing if you want a cool downtown location away from the crowds in Soho. Maybe this is normal in NYC though I've stayed plenty of hotels &amp; apartments before in NYC and NEVER come across this before. The fans are RIGHT by the beds so if you want to stay warm at night the noise means you can really barely sleep. Plus there's that unpleasant feeling of hot air blowing round the room.- WORSE, the bathrooms had NO heating WHATSOEVER.... We were there in a very mild November (T shirts some days) and this was unpleasant, so I can't imagine how uncomfortable this is when it's properly cold!!! Unbelievable!- We were told all rooms had the same issues (they acknowledged the building had been badly built!!).- The bathroom STANK of urine (sorry, but there's no other way to put it). It's probably just cheap cleaning fluid on cheap shower curtains, but combined with the above issues it didn't add to our feeling of comfort! And they couldn't fix this.The rooms were a good size and the beds were great however, but I wouldn't stay here again for the above reasons.FYI, if you're willing to not book in advance, when we were there friedns of ours were staying in the Mercer for LESS money than we paid for this hilton... and I'm comparing pay-in-advance Hilton best rates versus turn-up-on-the-door-and-see-what-the-best-rate is at the Mercer!!! Nov 17 2009 	Great Value Location and Staff	Off Soho had a mistake on its website about a rate. I called just to confirm instead of just booking on the site. I wasn't expecting wide open corridors with mile high ceilings. It was clean, fashionable, bright, and, comfortable. Upon arrival into the room it was a bit worn but large, very large actually, and well put together. One complaint is the couch/extra bed. It looks good but it is not practical or all that comfortable. Each of us had a hard time finding a comfortable position while relaxing between ventures out into the city. The bathroom, like the rest of the room was large too. The toilet warning sign means what it says. It is very low flow and don't try to flush too much TP in a sitting, give a lil and flush, and then go for another flush which kinda defeats the point of a low flow if you gotta flush a few times. The shower had great pressure and heat but both were a tad difficult to control at first. The room we had was easy to control some fresh air rather than use the AC. Overall, I think this hotel has a great location as it is close to several subway stops, many delicious restaurants, bars, and music venues. It's very close to Chinatown and Little Italy as well. I'd book here again even at a regular rate but was glad the staff gave me the rate listed on the website. That went a long way for me. I'd actually have to say that the biggest complaint was the internet available. It was slow and not very reliable.

	Clean pleasant convenient hotel.	My husband and I stayed here over Thanksgiving (2 nights). We purposely chose a hotel away from the craziness of the parade route, even though we knew we'd be going to watch it. This hotel is located less than one block from the W 4th St. subway entrance (a pleasant surprise), making it easy to come and go as we pleased. We quickly learned when getting off the subway here to follow exit signs for W 8th St. (not W 3rd). That brings you up to the Waverly Place and W 4th intersection, closest to the hotel. The hotel lobby is small, but clean and nicely decorated. There is only one small elevator, which was not a problem until morning hours when we had to wait for it to arrive. Continental breakfast was typical (croissants, muffins, fresh fruit, cereal, etc.) but I noticed people were waiting in line to be seated when we had finished. Glad we got there early. Our room was spacious for New York (if you can walk around the bed, it's spacious), and the bathroom was very clean and nicely appointed. I did not find the mattress that comfortable, but liked the bedding. The room was stuffy so we used the AC and it worked fine. Our windows looked out onto another building, but the view was unimportant to us since our plan was to go out and DO things vs. look out the window. However, it was a bit disconcerting to have no blinds/shade in the bathroom; just the bubbly privacy glass. And there WAS a room across the way where someone could have enjoyed voyeuristic views, I suppose. I just kept the bathroom light off. All in all, a pretty good experience.

	Meet our expectations- safe clean and comfortable	In NYC for Thanksgiving parade, etc. with family of 12 that includes four children ages 6-10. Hotel opened in early 2009 and is new. Hotel has 8 rooms per floor; four of the rooms face 40th Street while the other four rooms are on the back of the hotel. We had four rooms on the 27th floor. Two faced 40th Street while the other two rooms are on the back of the hotel and are quieter. Suggest you request rooms on back of hotel and higher floor for quietness. Rooms size is fine, clean with comfortable bed and pillows. Hotel has three elevators and even though the hotel was full the wait for an elevator was not long. Free breakfast was fine (coffee, hot chocolate, juice, fruit, cereal, toast, bagales, muffins, and biscuits with egg and meat). The free breakfast is nice benefit especially when you have kids. Breakfast room size is fine. 40th street is not the nicest but we always felt safe with our kids and never had a problem. There is a subway stop (40th Street and 8th Av.) within 150 feet of the hotel; you can also walk underground from this subway stop to the Times Square station which is great. The hotel is next to a Sheraton Four Points, and a new hotel is being built on the other side the Fairfield Inn. The hotel is across the street from a major bus terminal and it is easy to get a cab. We were there for 5 nights, our stay was fine, and we had no problems with this hotel. The hotel is fine for a family who wants to bring kids to NYC. It is safe, clean and comfortable.

She asked us three times if it was correct that we wanted a king size bed. When we assured her that it was correct she sneered and looked like she was going to be ill. Maybe she was, to her defense. It was not a warm greeting.The next day we asked the concierge what time the TKTS discount broadway ticket booth in Times Square opened and he said he had no idea and walked off. That stunned the both of us. Later on in the day a different concierge was on hand and was very helpful. The room was huge, comfortable and clean. The location can't be beat. 	Perfect boutique hotel in NYC	Hotel is quiet, streets are quiet at night. But hotel is close to pretty much everywhere you'll want to go. Short walk to Bryant Park, Grand Central Station. A little longer walk or short subway or cab ride to Rockefeller Center, Central Park and the Lower East Side. Rooms were pleasant with enough room to move around, leave luggage on floor, put things away, etc. Windows actually opened which was a nice touch that few hotels offer. Was able to easily open window to get a little cool air while packing. Beds were comfortable with lots of extra pillows; both sides of bed had little tables and lamps. Hotel decor happened to be exactly our style with bright colors; made everything feel more cheery. Excellent breakfast buffet at a reasonable price for NYC. No complaints. Staff all friendly and helpful. They seemed to have a brief problem with heat. At least that's what we were told when they delivered a space heater BEFORE we noticed any problem. Never needed to use it. Heat worked fine just a few hours later. Also nice that we found a superb rate on Kayak. They offer parking at a very reasonable rate for Manhattan, but we didn't even need to use it. Got great advice about where to park car to get free parking spaces within 2 blocks of hotel on weekdays and weekend. Don't know if we'll ever be able to afford the hotel again, but I'd love to go back.

	If the security of your belongings doesn't matter to you this hotel is probably fine.	This SHOULD have been a glowing review, but sadly, I would actively steer people AWAY from this hotel. Everything went along nicely during our 3 night stay --we thought the price was right, the location was good and the room and amenities were nice. Unfortunately, money vanished from our room safe and I would not feel safe staying in the hotel again....nor can I recommend the hotel to friends or colleagues. Here are the facts:We stayed in the hotel for 3 nights in mid November. During our stay, we used the hotel safe for our valuables and extra cash so we wouldn't have to carry it on the street. The night before we checked out, we took our valuables and some of the cash out of the safe, leaving $250 in the safe and locking it with our security code. We checked out the next day and though I am a very experienced traveler and always check the room thoroughly before checking out, we forgot to empty the safe. We left the hotel at 10 a.m. and only realized our mistake at 4pm when we immediately called the hotel.Supposedly, the security person on duty went to my room and used a hand held device which can over ride my personal security code. I waited on hold while he checked my room. When he got back on the phone, we said, &quot;I'm sorry, but the safe was empty&quot;.Of course, it is his word against mine, but I SAW the money in the safe and know it was locked when we left the room. If no one opened the safe in the meantime, how would you explain the vanishing act?I next talked to the head of security for the hotel several times. During our first conversation, he said that he personally went with the security person when our safe was opened. During our next conversation, when I pressed him on whether or not he SAW the safe being opened and that it was empty, he retracted his earlier statement and said, &quot;No, I didn't go to the room, I stayed at the elevator.&quot; Therefore,d the person who opened the safe had no witness. I found this revelation to be more than a bit disturbing. Why did he change his story?Next, I asked to speak to the hotel manager. I waited more than 5 hours to receive his call back. While he apologized on behalf of the hotel, he couldn't explain the discrepancy in the security staff's story and promised to &quot;get to the bottom of the situation and get back to me&quot;. I said that I looked forward to his full report and while I wish we could get our money back, I was more concerned about the hotel instituting a better security system and follow through. It has now been nearly two weeks since the incident and I haven't heard anything further from the manager......To his credit, he offered to offer a complimentary stay on a future visit, but until this issue is fully investigated and resolved, I wouldn't feel safe staying at the hotel.So....if you stay at the Empire Hotel, just remember that you are better off carrying your valuables with you. For the money that we lost, we could have upgraded to a better (and safer) hotel.One other point, during our stay, the lobby was closed off for an entire day as a TV show, Gossip Girl was being filmed there. I'm sure the hotel is compensated for the use of the space, but it added nothing but inconvenience to our stay as we had to go through alternate entrances, etc. It made me feel like the hotel was trying to use the space to make as much money as possible without any concern for how this might affect the guests. When I mentioned this issue to the front desk staff, they said the lobby was being used by a film crew nearly every week, so it is not a one off situation, but an on-going inconvenience to future guests.

Nov 18 2009 	A grand dame reawakens in splendor	The Pierre is one of New York's most iconic hotels and the Taj group have done a wonderful job in restoring the property to its former glory. I stayed for a few nights in early November and could not have been more enchanted. The location has always been beyond perfect, but the refurbishment that has been brought to both the public spaces and rooms is a great success. I very much enjoyed the classic yet contemporary feel in the rooms and was impressed with how the bathrooms had been reconfigured. The lobby atmosphere is lovely and only improved by the very charming staff that you come across throughout the hotel. A particular mention must go to the best elevator operators ever! I also shouldn't forget to say that the new restaurant Caprice and the new lobby bar appear to be quite the hot spots as both were busy well into the evening, even on nights earlier in the week when I was staying there. Overall, I hope Taj maintains the impressive efforts currently in place; if so the Pierre will be my only choice in New York.

Nov 23 2009 	Good stay - but avoid Rm 912	We chose to stay at the Bellclaire with our 3 year son as we were looking for a hotel on the upper west side close to Central Park and the Natural History Museum. Overall, its a very nice hotel, with clean, good size rooms with great hardwood floors. The beds are also very comfortable. Staff were friendly as well and the neighbourhood was appropriate for travelling with our 3 year old  more residential and less hectic than the mid-town area. We recommend the Bellclaire, but please stay away from room 912. On check-in we were given this room, which at first seemed fine until the night when there was this horrible hissing and clanking noise coming from this peculiar vent (pipe) in the bathroom. There was noise also from the street however that did not bother me since this is New York City after all. My husband went down to the front desk to enquire about a room change and was told that because the Bellclaire is an older hotel, all of the rooms had this problem and they could not guarantee that if we changed rooms the noise would be any better. I decided it was worth the risk to stay in another room and we moved to room 511 the next day where I immediate check the bathroom to see if it had another one of those peculiar pipes. No pipe  no noise, and I had two very comfortable nights of sleep. So, stay at the Bellclaire if you are looking for a reasonable place in the upper west side, but avoid room 912 at all cost! Other tips  the hotel is also close to the subway (the 1 Train (local) on 79 street and the 1,2,&amp;3 trains (express) on 72 street. There were also good choices for eating. 	Could not check in Hotel closed! Room was spacious, spotless, looked brand new, and very quiet - could not hear any noise from other rooms or the hallway. Hotel is quiet over weekends - it's busy during the week but at weekends it's a nice place to get away. Dined in the hotel's restaurant and was pleasantly surprised to get a free dessert on account of the special occasion - so the front desk had communicated to the restaurant that it was our anniversary. Thought this was a very nice touch. Room service breakfast the next morning overlooking the statue of liberty and ellis island was the perfect way to start the day. Highly recommended.

Nov 25 2009 	Good location 	If you want a central location and not pay a fortune, this one is OK. Not a 4-star quality but the rooms are adequate if somewhat tired, as are the public areas. Easy walking to most attractions and the concierge and reception staff were very helpful. Beware the bar closing before you can walk back after a show.	
	Great position and excellent rooms with a view	This was my third stay at the London in the past 12 months and it continues to be excellent.Book a &quot;Vista Suite&quot; and you will get a room with a separate, generously proportioned sitting area with a bay window and a big curved sofa where you can sit and read the New York Times over coffee and a spectacular view up Central Park (and both rivers if you are on a high enough floor). I really believe these rooms to be great value considering size/cost options of other mid town hotels of this standard. Located just a couple of blocks from the park, shopping on 5th avenue, Carnegie hall and only half a block from Moma, this is the ideal position for a long weekend in NYC. It feels like your very own private apartment. While some of the newer boutique (hip) hotels may eclipse the London for the &quot;cool factor&quot; , this hotel offers good looking, functional, immaculately clean rooms (that still smell brand new because they have never been smoked in) that are above all, quiet. I am getting too old to want to hear the thumping of a hotel bar at 3:00AM and the London is pleasantly peaceful. The restaurant food is good, especially the breakfast selection. The gym is very well equipped and there is free WiFi. The concierge department are very helpful but the doormen remain just a touch edgy. In all, you cannot go wrong with choosing the London.	
	Very Rude Staff Misleading Photos Good Location	Other than location this hotels offers very little. We will not stay there again. The front desk staff was consistently rude and unhelpful with the exceptions far and few between. The concierge, maintenance and cleaners are more friendly and helpful. The best way to describe the room is a patched up. Do not let the photos on the website deceive you. The walkways and room smell of old carpets. Hot water is a problem between 07:00 and 08:30 in the morning. We ended up not showering during these times. We also often had to flush the toilet more than once.But my overriding memory of this hotel is the rude front desk staff. At times it threatened to completely ruin our stay.

	Coulden't Fault	I was slightly sceptical about this hotel on reading some of the reviews for this site, but like my previous New York hotel (which had similar reviews), I decided to go ahead and book. On arrival I was quite surprised on how much smaller the lobby was compared to my previous New York hotel (Grand Hyatt), but it certainly didn't make it any less of a hotel. We checked in about 6pm and was greeted by a very helpful and polite man named Adelin or something similar who upgraded us into a corner room with a kitchenette and an amazing view. The room was very nice and clean, large and had the comfiest bed I have ever slept in. The staff were extremely friendly, especially one of the valet's. Not sure on the name either but he was always wore a large coat outside, always asking us if we enjoyed our day and always stopped for a chat.The location of the hotel isn't that bad, you have to walk a bit further than a few hotels but we're only talking 5-10minute walk to Grand Central but there is always Taxi's outside ready for business.I didn't try the room service/hotel restaurant because I never normally will pay the prices but room service didn't seem THAT expensive. We got breakfast every morning from a little place on the corner of 44th + 2nd called Plaza Delhi which did the most amazing pancakes and bagels at really good prices (2 cream cheese bagels + 3 large pancakes with syrup + 2 large coffee's for $9.95).We didn't really try any of the hotel facilities such as the pool and gym etc, we planned to but didn't really find the time/didn't have the energy after walking around NY all day.I would definitely stay at this hotel again, we stayed over thanksgiving and we got a really good price for the hotel on a advance booking through their own site. I would recommend this hotel to anyone.	
	perfectly acceptable	We stayed here on our return from Canada and Boston, having spent a week at the Hotel 17 a few weeks before. This hotel has a more modern decor and was quite adequate. We had a thermometer with us and it was 35 degrees celsius at 3am the first night. We tried to open a window, but the window fell out of its tracks and took a lot of effort to replace. Every night it became unbearably hot and we were sweating - confusing given it was 5 degrees outside. Apart from that the service was friendly, and they kept our bags both before and after we checked out for a few hours. Nov 23 2009 	Never Dissappointed at the Blakely!	The Blakely Hotel will always be my sentimental favorite as it was the first hotel I ever stayed at in NYC; back when it was still the Gorham. There are reasons we continue to return: consistent service, great location and helpful staff.I had booked 2 rooms for 4 people thru Quikbook and called several nights before to confirm the reservations and was told that I had booked a one-bed room for both parties. I insisted that this was not the case and that a two-bed room had been booked for the two singletons traveling together. The manager was very nice and assured me that he would do everything in his power to see that we got a two-bed room. When we checked in, we had been upgraded to a suite (score!). The other two members of our party were not as lucky and were given the smallest room I had ever seen at this hotel.(we checked in mid-to-late afternoon and they got the room you would expect if your flight was delayed and you didnt get to the hotel until 2AM) When they asked to be moved, they were relocated immediately to a larger room (with two beds) The midtown location is great. Close enough to the theatre district to walk, but not so close that youre in the middle of the throngs of people all the time.A complimentary continental breakfast at the adjoining restaurant has been added since my last stay and was basic toast, pastries, etc. but was enough for breakfast. The restaurant staff, however, were less that attentivewe almost had to mug one to get coffee one morning.I had stayed in a suite at the Blakely before and again was not disappointedmy ONLY complaint was that the bathroom is far far away from the sleeping area making for a long trek in the middle of the night. We were on only the 2nd floor, but street noise was never an issue and the blackout drapes assured we slept well. The room and bathroom were immaculately clean and all staff that I encountered were helpful and friendly. Getting upgraded to the suite was really a godsend when I got sick and stayed in the room way more that anyone usually would during a trip to New York City.I discovered the day after returning home that I had left my cell phone charger. When I called to inquire, the Housekeeping Director was gone for the day and actually called me back as I asked! My charger was returned promptly and in good order. Overall, you just cant go wrong at the Blakely.

	Trendy modern  not for all tastes	This hotel is best for a romantic getaway type of deal. I'd give this 4 stars were it not for the loud cracking noise from the heating system. The regular rate is $200+ for a petite, which is overpriced unless you can get an upgrade to a queen or larger. If you are into sleek, dark, masculine, and more modern/trendy style it's for you. If you're into classic, warmth, coziness, than you should try something else. It has an excellent location. I got a special deal through hotels.com at the last minute. They upgraded me to a queen room with a terrace, which was awesome, and probably worth the money (~$160). They also let me check in 2 hours early. The look is very dark, masculine, and romantic. Television behind the mirror, nice entertainment system. Nice bath products, and a sexy bathroom set up (dark walls, mirrored walls, etc.) It would not suit all people's tastes, it's very modern and &quot;cold&quot;. The staff is very helpful, but not that friendly. There were loud cracking/drilling noises that I was told was due to the heating generator. I had to turn off the heat to get rid of the noise. I ordered room service for breakfast and it was neither generous nor that tasty. They give you cookies, which is nice. Overall, I'd say good for the younger, trendy set that's looking for a weekend away together. I liked the bathroom. Would not pay more than $200 to stay here - for that price, you could find something nicer.
